newsitem.title: HONG KONG: S&P's new rating system useful but not perfect.
newsitem.headline: S&P's new rating system useful but not perfect.

text.p: Standard and Poor's local currency debt ratings for Asian banks based on public information are a useful, if not perfect, new tool for international investors, analysts said on Monday.

"There are a lot of reasonably conservative investors that don't want to jump into what they consider emerging markets," said Imre Speizer, director of local fixed income trading for SBC Warburg in Singapore.
"But with an implied rating from S&P, I think it will open the door a little more for them," he said.
S&P on Monday assigned public information ratings to six Singapore banks, 13 Indonesian banks and 14 Philippine banks.
The move followed the rating agency's announcement last week that it would expand its worldwide bank coverage by assigning ratings based on information available to the public.
S&P said it would assign about 250 new bank ratings, mostly in emerging markets, in the next year.
It said the new ratings would be distinguished from its full debt ratings, which involve lengthy consultations with the issuer, by a "pi" attached to the familiar letter grade.
It will assess Japanese regional banks in December. Hong Kong, Malaysian and Thai banks will be rated in January, with Taiwan banks set to receive grades shortly thereafter.

"We are seeing a lot of investors that want to know more about the bank issuers, and I think that the ratings that S&P have given them will provide them with a level of comfort," said Damien Wood, assistant director at Peregrine Fixed Income in Hong Kong.

Graeme Lee, S&P managing director in Melbourne, said the new ratings are an extension of the agency's risk evaluation service, which provides similar public information-based assessments using a less precise scale than the letter grades.
Analysts cautioned that while unsolicited ratings are useful, they are less thorough than traditional ratings.
"They are still a long way off from being as useful as a proper rating because the big problem in this part of the world is the lack of disclosure of meaningful information," said SBC's Speizer.
Such ratings are "basically an information assistance service" that will aid investors that don't have the resources to study the public documents themselves, he said.
Peregrine's Wood said he suspected that the "pi" ratings are a "fairly good indication of what they would be if the agency had been through the full due diligence process".
But he noted that the possibility of S&P making mistakes is higher with unsolicited ratings.
Rival rating agency Moody's Investors Service already makes assignments that are not solicited by the rated entity, but these are not distinguished from its standard ratings.

"The implication is that we will probably see more ratings coming out of both agencies, which is good for credit analysts and good for investors," said Evelyn Lam, senior credit analyst at Banque Indosuez in Hong Kong.
Many Asian countries have one or more local credit rating agencies that assess a domestic issuer's ability to service debt obligations versus other borrowers in the country.

Analysts said that while local investors rely on the domestic agencies, international investors are more comfortable with the global agencies, which assess each issuer in a worldwide context using standardised criteria.
Banque Indosuez's Lam said that in a best-case scenario the international rating agencies would combine with the domestic agencies to marry proven methodology with local knowledge.
S&P, Moody's and other international rating agencies have provided assistance to some of the local Asian agencies through cooperation agreements and other arrangements.
